bioghist.p: Thomas Fletcher (1787-1866) was a Philadelphia silversmith. His partner in business was Sidney Gardiner. In Boston in 1808, he and Sidney Gardiner founded the firm Fletcher & Gardiner. In 1811, they moved the firm to Philadelphia. Between 1811 and 1826, the firm received many important commissions for commemorative or presentation silver pieces. They made several pieces for heroes of the War of 1812, including Isaac Hull, Jacob Jones, James Biddle and Oliver Hazard Perry. Thomas Fletcher was one of the five original founders of the Franklin Institute. After Sidney Gardiner's death in 1827, Fletcher carried on the business. From 1836 to 1839, he was a partner with Calvin Wilder Bennett (operating as Fletcher & Bennett). Thomas Fletcher's brothers Charles and George were also silversmiths and jewelers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Fletcher family of Philadelphia, including Timothy Fletcher and his children Thomas, Charles, Melanie, George, Frank, James, and Levi, as well as his grandson Veron Fletcher. The bulk of the materials relate to the life and business activities of Thomas Fletcher. Business materials include correspondence (of the firms Fletcher & Gardiner, Fletcher & Bennett, and Baldwin & Fletcher); bills of lading; freight lists; indentures and agreements; commissions and orders for vases, swords, necklaces, and communion vessels. Fletcher family papers include correspondence; wills and deeds; estate papers; personal essays and poetry; clippings; genealogical records; marriage certificates; passports; and a small number of records of personal investments. Notable items in the collection include statements of Fletcher family members made upon the laying of the cornerstone of their country house in 1899; and a plan of lots in Delanco, New Jersey belonging to the estate of Thomas Fletcher. The collection also includes some papers of George Dummer.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
